p1: The Bronze Age in the Indian subcontinent began around 3300 BCE. The Indus Valley was one of the three major cradles of Old World civilization, with a population possibly exceeding five million at its peak. The Indus civilization was primarily centered in modern-day Pakistan's Indus river basin and the Ghaggar-Hakra basin. It flourished from 2600 to 1900 BCE, marking the rise of urban life in the Indian subcontinent. Major cities included Harappa, Mohenjo-daro (Pakistan), and Dholavira, Lothal (India).
p2: During the 2nd millennium BCE, the Ochre Coloured Pottery culture thrived in the Ganga-Yamuna Doab region. These rural settlements practiced agriculture, hunting, and used copper tools like axes, spears, arrows, and swords, along with domesticated animals.
title: Lothal
description: Lothal, a key city of the Harappan civilization, was a major port in present-day Gujarat, India. Dating back to around 2400 BCE, it played a crucial role in trade, connecting the Indus Valley to regions like Mesopotamia.
